chunks.text: These numbers have gone way up.  Now, where have they gone up the most?  Well, it used to be that childhood mortality  was enormous.  And so if you look at 1851, by age 10, about 30% of children

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: had died.  And so we've gotten a lot better at stopping that from happening.  People also look at curves like this.  So this is a distribution of death rates by age.  This happens to be for Japan a few years ago.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: And again, females do better than males.  The gold curve in the middle is the average of the two.  And this is very typical of almost any country  that you look at.  The shape of this curve is pretty universal.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: So what does this say?  It says that when you're born, there's a relatively high risk  that you're going to die.  So these are kids who have congenital abnormalities,  have prenatal problems, have all kinds of difficulties,

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: and they don't make it.  So there's a fairly high death rate at birth.  But once you make it to about, I think, about two years old,  the death rate is down to about 1 in 10,000 per year.  And then it stays quite low until you become a teenager.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: Now, why might the death rate go up when you become a teenager?  Suicide?  Well, suicide is the extreme example of that.  But teenagers tend to be risk-seeking rather than  risk-averse.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: They start driving cars.  They go skiing, skydiving, whatever  it is that they're doing.  And they start dying.  But then if you make it to about 20,

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: then there's a relatively flat region, where by then you've  developed enough sense to know what risks are worth taking  and which ones aren't.  And so it's relatively flat until about age 35 or 40,  at which point it starts inexorably rising.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: And of course, as you get older and older,  the probability that you're going  to die in the next year becomes higher and higher.  This is uncomfortable for somebody  with my amount of gray hair.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: Now, there is a peculiarity in Japan  which people puzzled over for a while,  and that is that weird dip up at age 106.  So first of all, that's a very small number of people  that that represents.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: And it turned out that it was fraud.  So there were families who failed  to report the death of their ancient grandmother  or great-grandmother because they  wanted to continue collecting Social Security

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: payments from the government.  So that's an artifact.  Now, this is a serious problem which  we're going to return to in a more technical way  later in the semester, which is this problem of disparities.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: So if you look at, for example, the difference  between white and black female life expectancy in the United  States, you see that everybody's life expectancy,  as we've shown, is going up gradually, in this case,  from 1975 to 2015.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: But there continues to be a gap between black and white females  and between black and white males,  where black patients are more likely to die or less  likely to survive longer, given the disparities that exist  socioeconomically, maybe medically.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: We don't know exactly.  And then if you look at Hispanics,  however, they do pretty well.  So in 2015, you're actually a little bit better  off to be Hispanic, either male or female,

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: than you are to be either white or black.  But it's still worse to be black than to be white or Hispanic.  So these are the kinds of facts that  drive some of the issues in what we do in medical care.  Now, what do people die of?

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: Well, about a quarter of them die of heart disease,  and a little over a fifth of them die of cancer.  This is USA data from 2014, so it's not completely up to date,  but hasn't changed that much.  And then there's a decreasing number

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: of deaths from various other causes.  So heart disease, cancer, chronic lower respiratory  disease, so this is like COPD that's caused by smoking,  stuff like that.  Accidents account for about 5% of deaths.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: Stroke, cerebrovascular events, Alzheimer's disease, diabetes,  influenza, and pneumonia, kidney disease, suicide,  and then everything else is about another quarter.  Now, take a look at those.  What kind of diseases are these, the biggies?

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: Well, they're chronic.  Most of them are chronic.  They're also not infectious.  Except for influenza and pneumonia,  nothing else there is infectious as far as we know.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: That asterisk you should put after every statement  about current medicine.  So that's interesting, because if you wrote the same table  back in 1850, you would find that a lot of people  were dying of infections.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: And they weren't typically living long enough  to develop these lovely chronic diseases of the aging.  So there have been big changes there.  Now, the other thing that's worth looking at  is in addition to the reasons that people die,

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: they start getting sicker.  And they are getting sort of less value out of life,  because they're developing all these other conditions.  So if you look at people over 65, about half of them  have arthritis, some form of arthritis.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: And about 40% have hypertension.  By the way, if you have trouble with any of the medicalese  words, just interrupt.  Hypertension is high blood pressure.  Hearing impairment, me, I'm wearing a hearing aid

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: on one side, because my ears are going bad.  Heart disease, about a quarter.  Orthostatic impairment, that means people  who wobble because their sense of balance is not so good,  16%.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: Cataracts, chronic sinusitis, visual impairment,  genitourinary problems, diabetes, et cetera.  So these are all growing.  Here's the list of the next 10.  And varicose veins, hernia, hemorrhoids, psoriasis,

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: hardening of the arteries, tinnitus,  corns, calluses, constipation, hay fever,  and cerebrovascular problems.  So people develop these by the time they're over 65.  So one question we might ask is, well,

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: what is the quality of life?  So for example, a lot of the doctors  that I started working with in the 1970s  were great advocates of the application of decision  analysis, decision theory, to making medical decisions.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: And so the problem is, how do you evaluate an outcome?  And they said, well, the way we evaluate an outcome  is we look at your longevity.  Obviously, the longer you live, the better, typically.  But we also look at your quality of life during that time.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: And we say that if you're confined to a wheelchair,  let's say, your quality of life might not  be as good as if you were able to run around.  Or if you're suffering from chronic pain,  your quality of life might not be as good

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: as if you were pain-free.  And so we came up with this model that says, well,  the value of your life is essentially  an integral from time 0 to however long  you're going to live of a function q that

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: says this is a measure of how good your quality of life  is at that particular point in time,  and then some discount factor.  So what's the role of the discount factor?  Well, it's just like in economics.

chunks.title: part.001.mp3
chunks.text: If I offer you some horribly painful thing today  versus 10 years from now, which are you going to choose?  Most of us will say later.
